sub_topic: Using the Fourier transform to solve electromagnetic problems
message_1:
Calculate the Fourier transform of the following electromagnetic function:

f(t) = 2cos(3πt) + 4sin(4πt)

where t ranges from -∞ to +∞.
message_2:
To calculate the Fourier transform of the given function, we will use the following definition of the Fourier transform:

F(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} f(t) e^(-jωt) dt

where F(ω) is the Fourier transform of f(t), ω is the angular frequency, and j is the imaginary unit (j^2 = -1).

Given the function:

f(t) = 2cos(3πt) + 4sin(4πt)

We will calculate the Fourier transform for each term separately and then add the results.

First term: 2cos(3πt)

F1(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} 2cos(3πt) e^(-jωt) dt

Second term: 4sin(4πt)

F2(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} 4sin(4πt) e^(-jωt) dt

Now, we can use the following Euler's formula to rewrite the trigonometric functions in terms of complex exponentials:

cos(x) = (e^(jx) + e^(-jx))/2
sin(x) = (e^(jx) - e^(-jx))/(2j)

Rewriting the first term:

F1(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} [e^(j3πt) + e^(-j3πt)] e^(-jωt) dt

And the second term:

F2(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} [e^(j4πt) - e^(-j4πt)] e^(-jωt) dt

Now we can integrate each term separately:

F1(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} e^(j(3π-ω)t) dt + ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} e^(-j(3π+ω)t) dt

F2(ω) = ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} e^(j(4π-ω)t) dt - ∫_{-∞}^{+∞} e^(-j(4π+ω)t) dt

These integrals are Dirac delta functions:

F1(ω) = π[δ(ω - 3π) + δ(ω + 3π)]
F2(ω) = (1/j)2π[δ(ω - 4π) - δ(ω + 4π)]

Now we can add F1(ω) and F2(ω) to get the Fourier transform of the original function:

F(ω) = F1(ω) + F2(ω) = π[δ(ω - 3π) + δ(ω + 3π)] + (1/j)2π[δ(ω - 4π) - δ(ω + 4π)]

This is the Fourier transform of the given function f(t) = 2cos(3πt) + 4sin(4πt).
